questions.text: A 44-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of a 1-month history of fatigue and difficulty swallowing. During this period, she has also had dry skin, thinning hair, and rounding of her face. She has type 1 diabetes mellitus and rheumatoid arthritis.  Her father had a thyroidectomy for papillary thyroid cancer. The patient had smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years but quit 3 years ago. She drinks 2–3 glasses of wine daily. Her current medications include insulin, omeprazole, and daily ibuprofen. She appears well. Her temperature is 36.3°C (97.3°F), pulse is 62/min, and blood pressure is 102/76 mm Hg. Examination of the neck shows a painless, diffusely enlarged thyroid gland. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Spindle cells, pleomorphic giant cells, and mitotic figures on thyroid biopsy
Large irregular nuclei, nuclear grooves, and Psammoma bodies on thyroid biopsy
Increased uptake in a discrete 1-cm area on a radioactive iodine scan
Uniform and diffusely increased uptake on a radioactive iodine scan
Positive TSH receptor antibodies and thyroglobulin antibodies in serum
Positive thyroid peroxidase antibodies and thyroglobulin antibodies in serum

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Spindle cells, pleomorphic giant cells, and mitotic figures would be seen on a biopsy of anaplastic thyroid cancer, which typically presents with a rapidly enlarging neck mass. Such a neck mass may cause pain or compressive symptoms, such as hoarseness or dysphagia, the latter of which the patient has. However, anaplastic thyroid cancer is not typically associated with symptoms of hypo- or hyperthyroidism.

B) INCORRECT:

Large, irregular nuclei, nuclear grooves, and Psammoma bodies would be seen on a biopsy of papillary thyroid cancer, which typically presents as a discrete thyroid nodule. A history of rapid enlargement and evidence of surrounding tissue involvement, such as nodule fixation, hoarseness, or vocal cord paralysis, would increase suspicion of malignancy. Although this patient does have dysphagia and a positive family history, her thyroid gland is diffusely enlarged without a discrete nodule. Also, papillary thyroid cancer is not typically associated with clinical hypo- or hyperthyroidism.

C) INCORRECT:

A discrete area of radioactive iodine uptake (hot nodule) may be seen in toxic adenomas, which primarily present with symptoms of hyperthyroidism. However, this patient presents with symptoms of hypothyroidism, which is inconsistent with the diagnosis of toxic adenoma and its associated findings on a radioactive iodine scan.

D) INCORRECT:

A uniform and diffusely increased radioiodine uptake would be suggestive of Graves disease, which can manifest with goiter but it causes features of hyperthyroidism (e.g., tachycardia, moist skin, weight loss) rather than hypothyroidism. Patients with Hashimoto thyroiditis have a highly variable tracer uptake on a radioactive iodine scan with diffusely decreased radioiodine uptake reported in approx. 30% of patients.

E) INCORRECT:

An elevation of both TSH receptor antibodies (TRAb) and thyroglobulin antibodies (TgAb) is a typical finding in patients with Graves disease, which can manifest with a goiter but would cause symptoms of hyperthyroidism (e.g., weight loss, anxiety, tremor, sweating, palpitations), not hypothyroidism. TRAb is less commonly seen in patients with Hashimoto's thyroiditis (only approx. 10–15% of cases).

F) CORRECT:

Thyroid peroxidase (TPO) and thyroglobulin (Tg) are typically only present in the thyroid gland and thus sequestered from the systemic immune system. In Hashimoto thyroiditis, genetic and environmental factors are thought to cause immune sensitization to self-antigens such as TPO and Tg, which results in chronic inflammation of the thyroid gland. As such, thyroid peroxidase antibodies (TPOAb) and thyroglobulin antibodies (TgAb) can be detected in the majority of patients with Hashimoto thyroiditis and can be used to assess disease activity (see “Overview of thyroid antibodies” table).

Radioactive iodine scan is not part of the regular workup of Hashimoto thyroiditis; the findings are highly variable but iodine uptake may be decreased in transient thyrotoxicosis. A thyroid biopsy would show diffuse lymphocytic infiltration with Hurthle cells and fibrotic tissue. Patients with Hashimoto thyroiditis also have a high risk of developing a thyroid lymphoma; a thyroid lymphoma should be suspected if a patient with Hashimoto thyroiditis has a rapidly growing goiter.
questions.hint: This patient has a diffusely enlarged thyroid (goiter), symptoms of hypothyroidism (fatigue, dry skin, hair thinning, rounding of the face), and a history of autoimmune conditions, which makes Hashimoto thyroiditis the most likely diagnosis. A large goiter can cause dysphagia due to esophageal compression.

questions.text: A previously healthy 6-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of slowed growth and fatigue. Over the past year, she went from average height for her age group to the shortest in her class. She has also been having more problems concentrating in class and is less interested in playing. She has not had any change in appetite or diet. She is at the 10th percentile for height and the 90th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. There is a nontender mass palpated on the anterior neck during cervical examination. Serum laboratory studies show thyroid-stimulating hormone level of 6.7 μU/mL. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Lymphocytic infiltration on fine needle aspiration
Positive serum thyroid stimulating hormone receptor antibody
Solitary hot nodule on I-131 scan

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An increased ESR in a patient with goiter may indicate subacute thyroiditis, which most often occurs in women 30–50 years and presents with a painful, diffuse, and firm goiter, and a clinical course of hyperthyroidism, followed by hypothyroidism, and finally a return to euthyroidism over the span of several months. In a subtype, called subacute lymphocytic thyroiditis, the goiter is painless. While this child presents with a nontender cervical mass and hypothyroidism, in her age group the condition is extremely rare. In Hashimoto thyroiditis, ESR is usually normal.

B) INCORRECT:

An elevated serum calcitonin is highly sensitive, but non-specific, for medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC). Children with MTC typically present with an asymptomatic solitary nodule. However, MTC is not typically associated with clinical hypo- or hyperthyroidism. Moreover, MTC in children is highly associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia 2 (MEN 2); this patient has no evidence to suggest MEN 2A (e.g., symptoms of pheochromocytoma, symptoms of hyperparathyroidism) or MEN 2B (e.g., marfanoid habitus, multiple neuromas).

C) CORRECT:

Diffuse lymphocytic infiltration next to germinal centers (i.e., sites of antibody-secreting plasma cells), Hurthle cells, and fibrotic tissue are characteristic findings of Hashimoto thyroiditis. In Hashimoto thyroiditis, T-lymphocytes are cytotoxic to thyroid epithelial cells and stimulate B lymphocytes to produce autoantibodies (e.g., anti-peroxidase and anti-thyroglobulin), which results in progressive destruction of thyroid tissue and consequent hypothyroidism. Lifelong oral administration of L-thyroxine (T4) is the treatment of choice.

Other causes of pediatric hypothyroidism include thyroid dysgenesis (most common cause of congenital hypothyroidism in areas with adequate iodine intake), iodine deficiency, TSH receptor resistance, and other rare conditions affecting the formation and transport of thyroid hormone.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of thyroid tissue (H&E stain)

The thyroid tissue in the lower half of the image is inflamed, as evidenced by the lymphocytic infiltrate (numerous purple dots) and dilated, congested blood vessels (examples indicated by arrows). Prominent lymphoid follicles with a germinal center (example indicated by orange overlay) surrounded by a hypercellular parafollicular region (example indicated by green overlay) are visible in the inflamed region. Normal thyroid follicles (example indicated by blue overlay) are visible in the top half of the image but are absent in the inflamed region.

Lymphocytic infiltration, lymphoid follicles with germinal centers, and destruction of thyroid follicles are characteristic features of Hashimoto thyroiditis.

D) INCORRECT:

Positive thyroid-stimulating hormone receptor antibodies (TRAb) are most characteristic of Graves disease (> 90% of cases). While patients with Graves disease also present with goiter, they have hyperthyroidism, rather than hypothyroidism as seen in this patient. TRAb are also found in up to 15% of patients with Hashimoto's thyroiditis, but thyroid peroxidase antibodies (> 90%) and thyroglobulin antibodies (∼ 50%) are much more common. Although this patient may be positive for TRAbs, another finding is more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased uptake on I-131 (i.e., radioactive iodine) scan in a discrete area (i.e., a solitary, hot nodule) is characteristic of a toxic adenoma, which typically affects adults 30–50 years of age and causes hyperthyroidism, rather than hypothyroidism as seen in this patient. Toxic adenomas are uncommon in children and radionuclide scanning is rarely indicated in children with primary hypothyroidism.

F) INCORRECT:

Low urine iodine levels indicate iodine deficiency, which can lead to hypothyroidism and goiter. However, with the introduction of iodized salt in the 1920's, iodine deficiency has become exceedingly rare in the US, making another condition much more likely. In developing countries where a low iodine diet is common, this patient's symptoms would most likely be the result of iodine deficiency.
questions.hint: This pediatric patient has fatigue, decreased growth velocity with weight gain, goiter, and elevated TSH, which are all consistent with primary hypothyroidism. In areas with adequate iodine intake, Hashimoto thyroiditis is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in both children and adults.

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of swelling in her legs. She has also had hoarseness for the past month. She lives in Texas and returned from a trip to Mexico 8 months ago. She has a history of hypertension, constipation, and coronary artery disease. She works as a teacher at a primary school. Her mother had type 2 diabetes mellitus. She drinks one glass of wine daily and occasionally more on the weekend. Current medications include aspirin, bisoprolol, and atorvastatin. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 82 kg (181 lb); BMI is 30 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows bilateral pretibial nonpitting edema. The skin is indurated, cool, and dry. Peripheral pulses are palpated bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. This patient is at increased risk for developing which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A renal vein thrombosis may be a complication of nephrotic syndrome, which commonly manifests with edemas. However, nephrotic syndrome typically starts with periorbital edema and later causes pitting edema. Furthermore, this patient does not present with frothy urine or signs of hypocalcemia while her nonpitting edema, constipation, obesity, voice hoarseness, and cool, dry skin make another diagnosis and potential complication more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Esophageal variceal hemorrhage is a complication of cirrhosis, which may manifest with dermatologic symptoms (e.g., spider angiomata, caput medusae, palmar erythema). The nonpitting edema in this patient and her additional symptoms of constipation, obesity, voice hoarseness, and cool, dry skin indicate a different diagnosis and another potential complication.

C) INCORRECT:

Proliferative retinopathy is often a complication of diabetes mellitus. While diabetes can manifest with dermatologic symptoms such as necrobiosis lipoidica, this patient does not have the typical erythematous plaques and ulcerations. In addition, nonpitting edema is not a common symptom of necrobiosis lipoidica, and this patient's additional symptoms of constipation, voice hoarseness, and cool, dry skin make another diagnosis and potential complication more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Elephantiasis is caused by lymphatic obstruction and can be primary (rare; characteristic finding in Turner syndrome) or secondary (e.g., due to tumors, trauma, infections). Although lymphedema can manifest with nonpitting edema, this patient's edema is most likely a consequence of hypothyroidism, which does not cause edema through lymphatic obstruction but rather through the deposition of glycosaminoglycans (myxedema).

E) CORRECT:

Hashimoto thyroiditis is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in the US and a risk factor for primary thyroid lymphoma.

F) INCORRECT:

Venous ulcers are a complication of chronic venous insufficiency (CVI), which manifests with lower extremity edema. Furthermore, this patient's obesity and occupation (being a teacher is associated with prolonged standing) put her at increased risk of developing CVI. However, edema in CVI is most commonly pitting. This patient's nonpitting edema and additional findings are most likely due to hypothyroidism, not CVI.

G) INCORRECT:

An arterial ulcer may result from peripheral arterial disease. However, this patient does not present with numbness, claudication, or weakness, and her intact distal pulses make another diagnosis and potential complication more likely.
questions.hint: The presence of constipation, nonpitting pretibial edema, hoarse voice, and indurated, cool, dry skin in an obese patient should raise concern for hypothyroidism, which, in the US, is most commonly caused by autoimmune thyroiditis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of fatigue over the past 6 months. During this period, the patient has also had a 5 kg (11-lb) weight loss. She has a history of Hashimoto thyroiditis. She is sexually active with her husband only. She does not smoke. She drinks one glass of wine per day. She does not use illicit drugs. Her only medication is levothyroxine. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows tenderness in the right upper quadrant with no rebound or guarding. Laboratory studies show a serum alanine aminotransferase level of 990 U/L, serum aspartate aminotransferase level of 850 U/L, and serum total bilirubin level of 1.1 mg/dL. Liver biopsy shows plasma cell infiltration and areas of periportal piecemeal necrosis. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although not specific, the presence of an elevated serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) in this patient would be suggestive of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). While her symptoms could also be seen with HCC, she has no risk factors (chronic hepatitis virus infection, chronic alcohol use, nonalcoholic fatty liver disease) and her biopsy results are not consistent with this diagnosis.

B) CORRECT:

The presence of serum antismooth muscle antibodies (ASMA) has a specificity of 80% for the diagnosis of type 1 AIH. Additional laboratory abnormalities in AIH often include positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) and increased serum IgG. AIH is also associated with other autoimmune conditions, such as Hashimoto thyroiditis.
Image Description:

Overview illustration comparing clinical features, epidemiology, pathophysiology, and diagnostics of primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), primary biliary cholangitis (PBC), and autoimmune hepatitis.

C) INCORRECT:

The presence of antimitochondrial antibodies (AMA) is classically associated with primary biliary cirrhosis (PBC). While this patient's symptoms and biopsy results could also be seen with PBC, she lacks the symptoms and findings of a cholestatic process (e.g., pruritus) that are typical for PBC.

D) INCORRECT:

The presence of a decreased serum ceruloplasmin concentration in this patient would be suggestive of Wilson disease. While her symptoms could also be seen with Wilson disease, she lacks additional findings to support this diagnosis (e.g., neurologic symptoms, Kayser-Fleischer rings). Liver histology may also show necrosis, as seen in this patient, but the use of copper staining would show elevated hepatic copper content.

E) INCORRECT:

The presence of hepatitis B surface antigen suggests acute or chronic infection with hepatitis B virus (HBV). While this patient's symptoms could also be seen with HBV infection, she has no risk factors for HBV infection (e.g., IV drug use, multiple sexual partners).

F) INCORRECT:

The presence of an elevated transferrin saturation in this patient would be suggestive of hemochromatosis; a transferrin saturation > 50% is ∼ 90% specific for this diagnosis. While this patient's symptoms could also be seen with hemochromatosis, she lacks additional findings to support this diagnosis (hyperpigmented skin, diabetes, arthralgias) and liver histology in hemochromatosis would most often show pronounced siderosis with iron deposits in hepatocytes.

G) INCORRECT:

The presence of positive perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (pANCA) is associated with several autoimmune conditions and in this clinical context would be suggestive of a diagnosis of primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC). While this patient's symptoms could also be seen with PSC, she lacks the symptoms and findings of a cholestatic process (e.g., pruritus) that are typical for PSC. Additionally, liver biopsy in PSC usually would demonstrate inflammation of the biliary duct epithelium, with the eventual development of portal and periportal fibrosis.

H) INCORRECT:

Antihepatitis C virus antibodies are found in individuals who have been exposed to hepatitis C virus (HCV). While this patient's symptoms could also be seen with HCV infection, she has no risk factors (e.g., IV drug use, multiple sexual partners).
questions.hint: This patient's age, lack of other risk factors, and biopsy results are highly suggestive of autoimmune hepatitis (AIH).

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 47-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of a 4-month history of worsening fatigue and constipation. She has also noticed that her cheeks appear fuller and her voice has become hoarse. Her temperature is 36.3°C (97.3°F) and pulse is 59/min. Examination of the neck shows a painless, mildly enlarged thyroid gland. Her skin is dry and cool and her nails appear brittle. Serum studies show antibodies against thyroid peroxidase. A biopsy of the thyroid gland is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Large, irregular nuclei, nuclear grooves, and Psammoma bodies
Extensive fibrosis, mixed inflammatory infiltrate, and obliterated follicles
Tall follicular cells, scalloped colloid, and vascular congestion
Spindle cells, pleomorphic giant cells, and mitotic figures
Multinucleated giant cells, macrophages, and degenerated follicular cells
Lymphocytic infiltration, Hürthle cells, and germinal centers

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Large, irregular nuclei, nuclear grooves, and Psammoma bodies are characteristic of papillary thyroid carcinoma, which typically presents as a discrete thyroid nodule. Patients may present with a hoarseness due to tumor infiltration of the recurrent laryngeal nerve; however, other features of hypothyroidism, a diffuse goiter, and anti-TPO antibodies would be absent.

B) INCORRECT:

Extensive fibrosis, mixed inflammatory infiltrate, and obliterated follicles are seen in Riedel thyroiditis, a rare form of autoimmune thyroiditis characterized by invasive, fibrous growth into the thyroid gland with the destruction of thyroid follicles. Patients may present similarly to this woman, with features of hypothyroidism and a goiter. However, anti-TPO antibodies would be absent.

C) INCORRECT:

Tall follicular cells, scalloped colloid, and vascular congestion are seen in Graves disease, in which the thyroid gland is excessively and persistently stimulated by circulating TRAbs. The active follicular cells are tall because they are producing and secreting thyroid hormones. The colloid is consumed during thyroid hormone synthesis, resulting in scalloped edges. Many patients with Graves disease have anti-TPO antibodies and a diffuse goiter, as seen here; however, patients would also have signs of hyperthyroidism, not hypothyroidism.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of thyroid tissue (H&E stain, 400x magnification)

Green overlay: papillary infoldings of hyperplastic thyroid follicles

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

D) INCORRECT:

Spindle cells, pleomorphic giant cells, and mitotic figures are seen in anaplastic thyroid cancer, which typically presents with a rapidly enlarging neck mass, usually in an elderly individual. Although patients may present with hoarseness (if there is tumor infiltration of the recurrent laryngeal nerve), features of hypothyroidism, a diffuse goiter, and anti-TPO antibodies would not be seen.
Image Description:

Photograph of the anterolateral aspect of the neck

The thyroid gland is diffusely enlarged in the region of the isthmus. A prominent nodule is visible in the right lateral aspect of the neck, which could be a nodule within the right lobe or a right lateral cervical lymphadenopathy.

Thyroid cancer typically manifests as a solitary, painless, firm to hard thyroid nodule with cervical lymphadenopathy. The diagnosis should be confirmed on cytological (i.e., fine-needle aspiration biopsy) or histopathological examination.

E) INCORRECT:

Multinucleated giant cells, macrophages, degenerated follicular cells, as well as neutrophilic and lymphocytic infiltration are seen in de Quervain thyroiditis (subacute granulomatous thyroiditis). Patients typically have a preceding viral illness and present with features of hyperthyroidism, followed by transient hypothyroidism before the spontaneous resolution of symptoms. Examination will show a tender diffuse goiter. Hoarseness and antithyroid antibodies are not features of de Quervain thyroiditis.

F) CORRECT:

Lymphocytic infiltration of the thyroid gland, germinal centers within the thyroid tissue, and Hurthle cells are histological hallmarks of Hashimoto thyroiditis, which is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient regions. Activated B cells organize into germinal centers within the thyroid gland and produce anti-thyroid peroxidase antibodies. The resulting autoimmune-mediated inflammation of the thyroid gland may result in a goiter, as seen in this patient. The destruction of follicles results in hypothyroidism.

Hoarseness in hypothyroidism (including Hashimoto thyroiditis) is due to the accumulation of glycosaminoglycans within the vocal cords.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of thyroid tissue (H&E stain)

The thyroid tissue in the lower half of the image is inflamed, as evidenced by the lymphocytic infiltrate (numerous purple dots) and dilated, congested blood vessels (examples indicated by arrows). Prominent lymphoid follicles with a germinal center (example indicated by orange overlay) surrounded by a hypercellular parafollicular region (example indicated by green overlay) are visible in the inflamed region. Normal thyroid follicles (example indicated by blue overlay) are visible in the top half of the image but are absent in the inflamed region.

Lymphocytic infiltration, lymphoid follicles with germinal centers, and destruction of thyroid follicles are characteristic features of Hashimoto thyroiditis.
questions.hint: This patient has a mildly enlarged thyroid, symptoms of hypothyroidism (fatigue, constipation, rounding of the face, brittle nails, hoarse voice), and anti-thyroid peroxidase antibodies, which is consistent with Hashimoto thyroiditis.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-week history of hoarseness and difficulty swallowing. She also has a history of lower back pain treated with ibuprofen. She is 162 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 77 kg (169 lb); BMI is 29 kg/m2. Her pulse is 64/min and blood pressure is 130/86 mm Hg. Physical examination shows dry skin, swelling of the lower extremities, and a hard nontender anterior neck swelling that does not move with swallowing. Femoral and pedal pulses are decreased bilaterally. A biopsy of the neck swelling is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Atypical nuclei and concentric lamellar calcifications
Spindle cells and areas of focal necrosis
Collagen deposition and decreased number of follicles
Lymphocytic infiltrate and germinal center formation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Psammoma bodies (characterized by concentric lamellar calcifications) and Orphan Annie eyes nuclei are histopathologic findings associated with papillary thyroid carcinoma. While patients with papillary thyroid carcinoma may present with a firm, immobile, and painless thyroid mass and symptoms of local compression (e.g., dysphonia and/or dysphagia), symptoms of hypothyroidism and retroperitoneal fibrosis are not associated with papillary thyroid carcinoma.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a thyroid tissue sample (H&E stain; high magnification)

Psammoma bodies are concentric lamellar calcifications that are often seen within papillary thyroid carcinomas.

Other tumors with frequent presence of psammoma bodies include serous carcinoma of the ovary, high-grade serous carcinoma of the uterus, and meningiomas.

B) INCORRECT:

The most frequently seen histopathology in anaplastic thyroid carcinoma involves spindle cells and giant cells. Since anaplastic thyroid carcinomas grow so rapidly, areas of focal necrosis are often seen due to lack of blood supply. While patients with anaplastic thyroid carcinoma may present with a firm, immobile, and painless thyroid mass and signs of local compression (e.g. dysphonia and/or dysphagia), signs of hypothyroidism and retroperitoneal fibrosis are not associated with anaplastic thyroid carcinoma.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a fine-needle aspiration from a thyroid lesion (H&E stain; medium magnification)

Highly pleomorphic cells (examples indicated by blue overlay) with enlarged, irregular nuclei that have prominent nucleoli (examples indicated by arrows) are visible. Multinucleated tumor cells (examples indicated by yellow overlay) can also be seen. There are no follicular or papillary growth patterns.

The diagnosis of an anaplastic thyroid carcinoma is a diagnosis of exclusion. This patient's diagnosis was supported by immunohistochemical findings (negative for TTF-1, thyroglobulin, and calcitonin).

C) CORRECT:

Chronic inflammation and collagen deposition (resulting in fibrosis) can lead to the destruction of thyroid follicles in patients with Riedel thyroiditis. If the fibrosis extends beyond the thyroid capsule into surrounding tissues, the swelling will be nonmobile and can lead to symptoms of local compression like hoarseness and dysphagia. Patients with Riedel thyroiditis are typically euthyroid, but about one-third of patients develop features of hypothyroidism (e.g., dry skin, weight gain). Riedel's thyroiditis is often associated with other IgG4-related diseases, such as retroperitoneal fibrosis or autoimmune pancreatitis.

There is no universal standard of treatment for Riedel thyroiditis. Medical treatment with corticosteroids +/- tamoxifen may reduce the size of the mass or slow down the progression of fibrosis. If the compressive symptoms are severe and not alleviated with medical therapy, debulking surgery may be indicated.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of an enlarged thyroid specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

Extensive fibrosis (examples indicated by blue overlay) with no intact thyroid follicles can be seen. There is a scattered lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate (examples indicated by yellow overlay) within the fibrotic stroma. Additionally, lymphocytic inflammation (examples indicated by arrows) in the walls of trapped veins can be seen.

The replacement of normal thyroid tissue with fibrosis is characteristic of Riedel thyroiditis (invasive fibrous thyroiditis).

D) INCORRECT:

Giant cells and noncaseating granulomas in a thyroid biopsy are consistent with subacute granulomatous thyroiditis. While patients with this condition may have thyroid swelling and may develop features of hypothyroidism (following transient hyperthyroidism), they typically present with a tender thyroid and have a history of recent viral or mycobacterial infection. Subacute granulomatous thyroiditis would also not explain the decreased pedal pulses.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a thyroid biopsy specimen (H&E stain)

A noncaseating granuloma composed of inflammatory cells (examples indicated by white arrowheads) engulfing colloid (acellular, pink, glassy substance; green overlay), numerous multinucleated giant cells (examples indicated by blue overlay), and a rim of fibrous tissue (yellow overlay) can be seen in the center of the image. The follicles in the region of the granuloma have been destroyed. Normal thyroid follicles (examples indicated by black arrowheads) are visible on the left.

This granulomatous destruction of thyroid tissue is characteristic of subacute granulomatous thyroiditis (de Quervain thyroiditis).

E) INCORRECT:

A lymphocytic infiltrate may be seen in Riedel thyroiditis due to chronic inflammation, but germinal centers do not form in this condition. Rather, germinal center formation combined with diffuse lymphocytic infiltration is characteristic of Hashimoto thyroiditis and Graves disease. While some of this patient's clinical features are consistent with Hashimoto thyroiditis (painless thyroid enlargement, hypothyroid symptoms, nonspecific myalgias such as backache) or Graves disease (e.g., painless thyroid enlargement, pretibial myxedema), neither of these two conditions would explain the decreased pedal pulses. Also, the patient does not have the hyperthyroidism or exophthalmos that are associated with Graves disease.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of thyroid tissue (H&E stain)

The thyroid tissue in the lower half of the image is inflamed, as evidenced by the lymphocytic infiltrate (numerous purple dots) and dilated, congested blood vessels (examples indicated by arrows). Prominent lymphoid follicles with a germinal center (example indicated by orange overlay) surrounded by a hypercellular parafollicular region (example indicated by green overlay) are visible in the inflamed region. Normal thyroid follicles (example indicated by blue overlay) are visible in the top half of the image but are absent in the inflamed region.

Lymphocytic infiltration, lymphoid follicles with germinal centers, and destruction of thyroid follicles are characteristic features of Hashimoto thyroiditis.
questions.hint: A hard fixed anterior neck swelling with features suggestive of retroperitoneal fibrosis (decreased lower limb pulsations, low backache, lower limb swelling) indicates Riedel thyroiditis.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman with type 1 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of fatigue and hair loss. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 15 years. Her only medication is insulin. Her pulse is 59/min and blood pressure is 102/76 mm Hg. Physical examination shows dry skin, coarse hair, and a nontender, diffuse neck swelling in the anterior midline. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Diffusely increased uptake on a radioactive iodine scan
Focal area of increased uptake on a radioactive iodine scan
Biphasic spindle cells on biopsy of the swelling
Dystrophic calcification on biopsy of the swelling
B8 subtype on HLA haplotype analysis
DR4 subtype on HLA haplotype analysis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

TSH receptor antibodies (TRAb) are found in 90% of patients with Graves disease, which can manifest with a thyroid swelling (goiter). However, it causes features of hyperthyroidism (e.g., tachycardia, moist skin, weight loss) rather than hypothyroidism. TRAb is seen in less than 15% of patients with Hashimoto thyroiditis. A different finding is much more likely.

B) CORRECT:

Thyroid peroxidase (TPO) is a microsomal enzyme. In Hashimoto thyroiditis, genetic and environmental factors are thought to cause immune sensitization to self-antigens such as TPO and thyroglobulin, resulting in chronic inflammation of the thyroid gland. As such, anti-TPO antibodies (formerly known as anti-microsomal antibodies) and anti-thyroglobulin antibodies can be detected in the majority of patients with Hashimoto thyroiditis and can be used to assess disease activity.

C) INCORRECT:

In the case of Hashimoto thyroiditis, radioiodine uptake is highly variable and extremely nonspecific. While decreased radioiodine uptake has been reported in approx. 30% of patients, a diffusely increased radioiodine uptake would be more suggestive of Graves disease. Graves disease can manifest with an anterior neck swelling (goiter), but it causes features of hyperthyroidism (e.g., tachycardia, moist skin, weight loss) rather than hypothyroidism. A different finding is much more likely in a patient with Hashimoto thyroiditis.

D) INCORRECT:

A discrete area of radioactive iodine uptake (hotspot) is most commonly caused by a toxic adenoma, which primarily manifests with features of hyperthyroidism (e.g., moist skin, tachycardia, weight loss) rather than hypothyroidism. Hashimoto thyroiditis, which is the most likely diagnosis in this patient, is associated with diffusely increased radioiodine uptake in 5–10% of patients, but discrete uptake (hotspot) would not be expected.
Image Description:

Nuclear medicine thyroid scintigraphy (Tc-99m pertechnetate)

The rounded area in the right thyroid lobe represents a so-called hot thyroid nodule, which shows increased radioisotope uptake compared to the rest of the thyroid gland.

E) INCORRECT:

Biphasic spindle cells, pleomorphic giant cells, and mitotic figures would be seen on a biopsy of anaplastic thyroid cancer, which typically manifests with a rapidly enlarging neck mass. However, anaplastic thyroid cancer is not typically associated with symptoms of hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism. Moreover, the rapidly enlarging neck mass of anaplastic thyroid cancer usually causes pain or compressive symptoms (e.g., hoarseness, dysphagia), which are not reported in this patient. Hashimoto thyroiditis, which is the most likely diagnosis, is associated with Hurthle cells and lymphocytic infiltrate with a germinal center on biopsy.

F) INCORRECT:

Dystrophic calcification (psammoma bodies) and large, irregular nuclei with grooves would be seen on a biopsy of papillary thyroid cancer, which typically manifests as a discrete thyroid nodule. This patient's thyroid gland is diffusely enlarged without a discrete nodule. Moreover, papillary thyroid cancer is not typically associated with clinical hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism.

G) INCORRECT:

HLA-B8 is associated with Addison disease, myasthenia gravis, and Graves disease. Addison disease can cause fatigue and hypotension, but it would be also manifest with cutaneous hyperpigmentation as a result of increased ACTH production. Myasthenia gravis (MG) can cause fatigue, but fatigue due to MG is classically worse in the evening or after activity and is associated with diplopia or ptosis. Graves disease can manifest with an anterior neck swelling (goiter), but it causes features of hyperthyroidism (e.g., tachycardia, moist skin, weight loss) rather than hypothyroidism. Hashimoto thyroiditis, which is the most likely diagnosis in this patient, is not associated with HLA-B8.

H) INCORRECT:

HLA-DR4 is associated with diabetes mellitus type 1, rheumatoid arthritis, and Addison disease, but not typically with Hashimoto thyroiditis, which is associated with HLA-DR3 and HLA-DR5. This patient with both T1DM and Hashimoto thyroiditis most likely has an HLA-DR3 haplotype.
questions.hint: In a patient with a history of an autoimmune condition (type 1 DM), a diffusely enlarged neck swelling (goiter) and symptoms of hypothyroidism (fatigue, dry skin, alopecia with coarse hair) make Hashimoto thyroiditis the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old girl presents with her mother, who states that the girl’s neck seems to have thickened. The girl’s weight has been stable, and she has not had any generalized swelling, heat or cold intolerance, difficulty breathing, or change in bowel or bladder habits.
Her temperature is 36.1°C, her heart rate is 70 beats per minute, and her respiratory rate is 14 breaths per minute. She appears well. Her neck is supple. The thyroid is firm and slightly enlarged; there are no palpable nodules.
Her serum thyroid-stimulating hormone level is 8.5 μU/mL (reference range, 0.5–4.0).
Which one of the following laboratory tests would support the most likely diagnosis for this child?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) receptor antibodies, such as TSH-binding inhibitory immunoglobulin, are a rare cause of hypothyroidism.

B) INCORRECT:

Levels of triiodothyronine (T3) are useful to measure only in the setting of hyperthyroidism, which occurs in patients who have Graves disease. Measuring T3 is unnecessary in the routine evaluation of thyroid function.

C) INCORRECT:

Thyroglobulin, a large protein, is usually measured as a tumor marker in patients with thyroid cancer who have undergone thyroidectomy and radioactive thyroid ablation. Obtaining a thyroglobulin level is not useful in patients who have not undergone thyroidectomy.

D) CORRECT:

Hashimoto thyroiditis, the most common form of thyroiditis in childhood, can manifest as an asymptomatic goiter; thyroid function can range from euthyroidism to subclinical hypothyroidism to overt hypothyroidism. Antithyroid peroxidase antibodies are present in the majority of patients with Hashimoto thyroiditis.

Key learning point: The antibody level that is most often elevated in a patient with Hashimoto thyroiditis is the antithyroid peroxidase antibody level.

E) INCORRECT:

Thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins are characteristically present in patients with Graves disease, which manifests with a low TSH level and symptoms of hyperthyroidism, such as tachycardia and weight loss.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman with type 1 diabetes mellitus comes to the office because of a 2-month history of fatigue and hair loss. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 15 years. Her only medication is insulin. Her pulse is 59/min and blood pressure is 102/76 mm Hg. Physical examination shows dry skin, coarse hair, and a nontender, diffuse neck swelling in the anterior midline. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Diffusely increased uptake on a radioactive iodine scan
Focal area of increased uptake on a radioactive iodine scan
Biphasic spindle cells on biopsy of the swelling
B8 subtype on HLA haplotype analysis

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Thyroid peroxidase (TPO) is a microsomal enzyme. In Hashimoto thyroiditis, genetic and environmental factors are thought to cause immune sensitization to self-antigens such as TPO and thyroglobulin, resulting in chronic inflammation of the thyroid gland. As such, anti-TPO antibodies (formerly known as anti-microsomal antibodies) and anti-thyroglobulin antibodies can be detected in the majority of patients with Hashimoto thyroiditis and can be used to assess disease activity.

B) INCORRECT:

In the case of Hashimoto thyroiditis, radioiodine uptake is highly variable and extremely nonspecific. While decreased radioiodine uptake has been reported in approx. 30% of patients, a diffusely increased radioiodine uptake would be more suggestive of Graves disease. Graves disease can manifest with an anterior neck swelling (goiter), but it causes features of hyperthyroidism (e.g., tachycardia, moist skin, weight loss) rather than hypothyroidism. A different finding is much more likely in a patient with Hashimoto thyroiditis.

C) INCORRECT:

A discrete area of radioactive iodine uptake (hotspot) is most commonly caused by a toxic adenoma, which primarily manifests with features of hyperthyroidism (e.g., moist skin, tachycardia, weight loss) rather than hypothyroidism. Hashimoto thyroiditis, which is the most likely diagnosis in this patient, is associated with diffusely increased radioiodine uptake in 5–10% of patients, but discrete uptake (hotspot) would not be expected.
Image Description:

Nuclear medicine thyroid scintigraphy (Tc-99m pertechnetate)

The rounded area in the right thyroid lobe represents a so-called hot thyroid nodule, which shows increased radioisotope uptake compared to the rest of the thyroid gland.

D) INCORRECT:

Biphasic spindle cells, pleomorphic giant cells, and mitotic figures would be seen on a biopsy of anaplastic thyroid cancer, which typically manifests with a rapidly enlarging neck mass. However, anaplastic thyroid cancer is not typically associated with symptoms of hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism. Moreover, the rapidly enlarging neck mass of anaplastic thyroid cancer usually causes pain or compressive symptoms (e.g., hoarseness, dysphagia), which are not reported in this patient. Hashimoto thyroiditis, which is the most likely diagnosis, is associated with Hurthle cells and lymphocytic infiltrate with a germinal center on biopsy.

E) INCORRECT:

HLA-B8 is associated with Addison disease, myasthenia gravis, and Graves disease. Addison disease can cause fatigue and hypotension, but it would be also manifest with cutaneous hyperpigmentation as a result of increased ACTH production. Myasthenia gravis (MG) can cause fatigue, but fatigue due to MG is classically worse in the evening or after activity and is associated with diplopia or ptosis. Graves disease can manifest with an anterior neck swelling (goiter), but it causes features of hyperthyroidism (e.g., tachycardia, moist skin, weight loss) rather than hypothyroidism. Hashimoto thyroiditis, which is the most likely diagnosis in this patient, is not associated with HLA-B8.
questions.hint: In a patient with a history of an autoimmune condition (type 1 DM), a diffusely enlarged neck swelling (goiter) and symptoms of hypothyroidism (fatigue, dry skin, alopecia with coarse hair) make Hashimoto thyroiditis the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl presents with her mother, who states that the girl’s neck seems to have thickened. The girl’s weight has been stable, and she has not had any generalized swelling, heat or cold intolerance, difficulty breathing, or change in bowel or bladder habits. Her temperature is 36.1°C, her heart rate is 70 beats per minute, and her respiratory rate is 14 breaths per minute. She appears well. Her neck is supple. The thyroid is firm and slightly enlarged; there are no palpable nodules. Her serum thyroid-stimulating hormone level is elevated. Which one of the following laboratory tests would support the most likely diagnosis for this child?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) receptor antibodies, such as TSH-binding inhibitory immunoglobulin, are a rare cause of hypothyroidism.

B) INCORRECT:

Levels of triiodothyronine (T3) are useful to measure only in the setting of hyperthyroidism, which occurs in patients who have Graves disease. Measuring T3 is unnecessary in the routine evaluation of thyroid function.

C) INCORRECT:

Thyroglobulin, a large protein, is usually measured as a tumor marker in patients with thyroid cancer who have undergone thyroidectomy and radioactive thyroid ablation. Obtaining a thyroglobulin level is not useful in patients who have not undergone thyroidectomy.

D) CORRECT:

Hashimoto thyroiditis, the most common form of thyroiditis in childhood, can manifest as an asymptomatic goiter; thyroid function can range from euthyroidism to subclinical hypothyroidism to overt hypothyroidism. Antithyroid peroxidase antibodies are present in the majority of patients with Hashimoto thyroiditis.

Key learning point: The antibody level that is most often elevated in a patient with Hashimoto thyroiditis is the antithyroid peroxidase antibody level.

E) INCORRECT:

Thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins are characteristically present in patients with Graves disease, which manifests with a low TSH level and symptoms of hyperthyroidism, such as tachycardia and weight loss.

questions.text:
A 43-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of progressive fatigue, weight gain, and constipation. She frequently feels cold and has noticed dry, coarse skin. She denies recent illnesses or childbirth. She reports occasional hoarseness of voice and mild hair loss over the past few months, but denies neck pain or difficulty swallowing. Physical examination reveals a mildly enlarged, non-tender thyroid gland (see lab results).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Thyroid-stimulating hormone
13.2 mIU/L
0.4 - 5.0 mIU/L


Thyroxine (T4 free)
8 pmol/L
8.5 - 15.2 pmol/L



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Subacute thyroiditis typically presents with painful thyroid tenderness and often follows a viral illness. It involves a triphasic course, starting with hyperthyroidism, then hypothyroidism, and finally resolution. The absence of pain and the chronic nature of the symptoms, along with the laboratory findings, suggest a different diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Postpartum thyroiditis occurs within the first year after childbirth and involves phases of hyperthyroidism followed by hypothyroidism. The patient denies recent childbirth, and the gradual progression of symptoms over six months without a postpartum context makes this diagnosis inappropriate.

C) CORRECT:

Hashimoto's thyroiditis manifests with symptoms of hypothyroidism, such as fatigue, weight gain, constipation, and cold intolerance. Laboratory findings show elevated thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) and low free thyroxine (T4), indicating primary hypothyroidism. This autoimmune condition involves lymphocytic infiltration and destruction of thyroid tissue, leading to decreased thyroid hormone production and compensatory TSH elevation. The presence of a mildly enlarged, non-tender thyroid gland is characteristic. These clinical and laboratory features, along with the autoimmune pathophysiology, confirm the diagnosis of Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

Key learning point: Hashimoto's thyroiditis is the most common cause of hypothyroidism and presents with symptoms such as fatigue, weight gain, and constipation.

D) INCORRECT:

Riedel's thyroiditis is characterized by a hard, fixed thyroid gland due to fibrotic replacement, often causing compressive symptoms like dysphagia. The thyroid in this case is mildly enlarged and non-tender, without compressive symptoms, making Riedel's thyroiditis unlikely.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old woman presents with a six-week history of progressive swelling in the anterior neck. She notes difficulty swallowing but no weight loss or voice changes. She denies fever or night sweats. She has a 12-year history of hypothyroidism and is on levothyroxine. Physical examination reveals a firm, mildly tender thyroid gland that has increased in size since her last exam. Laboratory testing, including TSH, is within reference range.
Which of the following is the most likely cause of her rapidly enlarging thyroid mass?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Papillary thyroid carcinoma is the most common thyroid malignancy, characterized by a slow-growing, painless nodule. It is often linked to radiation exposure rather than hypothyroidism. The rapid thyroid enlargement and compressive symptoms in this patient do not align with the typical presentation of papillary carcinoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Riedel thyroiditis involves fibrous tissue replacing normal thyroid tissue, leading to a firm thyroid and compressive symptoms. However, it progresses insidiously rather than rapidly. The patient's rapid thyroid enlargement and normal thyroid function tests are inconsistent with Riedel thyroiditis.

C) INCORRECT:

Medullary thyroid carcinoma originates from parafollicular C cells and usually presents as a firm, painless thyroid nodule. It typically follows an indolent course and is associated with elevated calcitonin levels or MEN2 syndromes, which are not mentioned here. The rapid enlargement and tenderness of the thyroid mass are inconsistent with medullary carcinoma.

D) CORRECT:

Primary thyroid lymphoma often arises in patients with a history of Hashimoto thyroiditis, due to chronic lymphocytic stimulation leading to lymphoid malignant transformation. It typically presents as a rapidly enlarging thyroid mass with compressive symptoms, such as difficulty swallowing, while thyroid function tests remain normal. The patient's firm, enlarging thyroid gland, history of hypothyroidism, and absence of systemic symptoms align with primary thyroid lymphoma.

Key learning point: Rapid enlargement of a neck mass in a patient with a history of Hashimoto thyroiditis is suggestive of thyroid lymphoma, a rare but known complication of chronic autoimmune thyroiditis.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman with type 1 diabetes mellitus comes to your clinic with a 2-month history of fatigue and hair loss. She has a 15-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily. Her only medication is insulin. Her pulse is 59/min and blood pressure is 102/76 mm Hg. On examination, she has dry skin, coarse hair, and a nontender, diffuse swelling in the anterior midline of the neck. Further evaluation is most likely to show which one of the following findings?

choices.text: B8 subtype on HLA haplotype analysis.
Focal area of increased uptake on a radioactive iodine scan.
Biphasic spindle cells on biopsy of the swelling.
Diffusely increased uptake on a radioactive iodine scan.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

HLA-B8 is associated with Addison disease, myasthenia gravis, and Graves disease. Addison disease can cause fatigue and hypotension, but it would be also manifest with cutaneous hyperpigmentation as a result of increased ACTH production. Myasthenia gravis (MG) can cause fatigue, but fatigue due to MG is classically worse in the evening or after activity and is associated with diplopia or ptosis. Graves disease can manifest with an anterior neck swelling (goiter), but it causes features of hyperthyroidism (e.g., tachycardia, moist skin, weight loss) rather than hypothyroidism. Hashimoto thyroiditis, which is the most likely diagnosis in this patient, is not associated with HLA-B8.

B) INCORRECT:

A discrete area of radioactive iodine uptake (hotspot) is most commonly caused by a toxic adenoma, which primarily manifests with features of hyperthyroidism (e.g., moist skin, tachycardia, weight loss) rather than hypothyroidism. Hashimoto thyroiditis, which is the most likely diagnosis in this patient, is associated with diffusely increased radioiodine uptake in 5–10% of patients, but discrete uptake (hotspot) would not be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Biphasic spindle cells, pleomorphic giant cells, and mitotic figures would be seen on a biopsy of anaplastic thyroid cancer, which typically manifests with a rapidly enlarging neck mass. However, anaplastic thyroid cancer is not typically associated with symptoms of hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism. Moreover, the rapidly enlarging neck mass of anaplastic thyroid cancer usually causes pain or compressive symptoms (e.g., hoarseness, dysphagia), which are not reported in this patient. Hashimoto thyroiditis, which is the most likely diagnosis, is associated with Hurthle cells and lymphocytic infiltrate with a germinal center on biopsy.

D) INCORRECT:

In the case of Hashimoto thyroiditis, radioiodine uptake is highly variable and extremely nonspecific. While decreased radioiodine uptake has been reported in approx. 30% of patients, a diffusely increased radioiodine uptake would be more suggestive of Graves disease. Graves disease can manifest with an anterior neck swelling (goiter), but it causes features of hyperthyroidism (e.g., tachycardia, moist skin, weight loss) rather than hypothyroidism. A different finding is much more likely in a patient with Hashimoto thyroiditis.

E) CORRECT:

Thyroid peroxidase (TPO) is a microsomal enzyme. In Hashimoto thyroiditis, genetic and environmental factors are thought to cause immune sensitization to self-antigens such as TPO and thyroglobulin, resulting in chronic inflammation of the thyroid gland. As such, anti-TPO antibodies (formerly known as anti-microsomal antibodies) and anti-thyroglobulin antibodies can be detected in the majority of patients with Hashimoto thyroiditis and can be used to assess disease activity.

Key learning point: Hashimoto thyroiditis is characterized by hypothyroidism and the presence of anti-thyroid peroxidase (anti-TPO) antibodies in serum.
questions.hint: In a patient with a history of an autoimmune condition (type 1 DM), a diffusely enlarged neck swelling (goiter) and symptoms of hypothyroidism (fatigue, dry skin, alopecia with coarse hair) make Hashimoto thyroiditis the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl comes to your clinic with her mother, who is concerned that her daughter's neck appears thicker. The girl's weight has been stable, and she has not experienced generalized swelling, heat or cold intolerance, difficulty breathing, or changes in bowel or bladder habits. Her temperature is 36.1°C, heart rate is 70/min, and respiratory rate is 14/min. Vital signs are normal. Her neck is supple. The thyroid is firm and slightly enlarged without palpable nodules. Her serum thyroid-stimulating hormone level is elevated (0.34–5.60). Which one of the following laboratory tests would support the most likely diagnosis for this child?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Levels of triiodothyronine (T3) are useful to measure only in the setting of hyperthyroidism, which occurs in patients who have Graves disease. Measuring T3 is unnecessary in the routine evaluation of thyroid function.

B) CORRECT:

Hashimoto thyroiditis, the most common form of thyroiditis in childhood, can manifest as an asymptomatic goiter; thyroid function can range from euthyroidism to subclinical hypothyroidism to overt hypothyroidism. Antithyroid peroxidase antibodies are present in the majority of patients with Hashimoto thyroiditis.

Key learning point: The antibody level that is most often elevated in a patient with Hashimoto thyroiditis is the antithyroid peroxidase antibody level.

C) INCORRECT:

Thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins are characteristically present in patients with Graves disease, which manifests with a low TSH level and symptoms of hyperthyroidism, such as tachycardia and weight loss.

D) INCORRECT:

Thyroglobulin, a large protein, is usually measured as a tumor marker in patients with thyroid cancer who have undergone thyroidectomy and radioactive thyroid ablation. Obtaining a thyroglobulin level is not useful in patients who have not undergone thyroidectomy.

E) INCORRECT:

Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) receptor antibodies, such as TSH-binding inhibitory immunoglobulin, are a rare cause of hypothyroidism.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents with a 4-month history of fatigue and weight gain. Physical examination shows a moderately enlarged thyroid that is painless and symmetrically enlarged with a rubbery consistency. She is afebrile with normal vital signs. Laboratory studies show a normal CBC, TSH 12.5 mcU/mL (normal 0.4–4.0), and free T4 0.7 ng/dL (normal 0.9–1.7). Which condition best explains these findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – Hashimoto thyroiditis typically presents with a painless, rubbery goiter with symmetrical enlargement and symptoms of hypothyroidism. The laboratory findings of elevated TSH and decreased free T4 indicate overt hypothyroidism, which is consistent with late-stage Hashimoto thyroiditis.

B) INCORRECT:

Subacute granulomatous thyroiditis presents with neck pain and tenderness, often accompanied by fever and systemic symptoms. The painless nature of the thyroid enlargement and absence of inflammatory signs make this diagnosis unlikely. While subacute lymphocytic thyroiditis can present with painless goiter and hypothyroidism, the chronic 4-month progression and lack of preceding hyperthyroid symptoms make a different diagnosis more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Riedel thyroiditis presents with a hard, stone-like, fixed goiter rather than the rubbery consistency described. This rare condition may cause compressive symptoms due to its firm, fibrotic nature, which differs from the clinical findings in this case.

D) INCORRECT:

Graves disease typically presents with symptoms of hyperthyroidism rather than the symptoms of hypothyroidism seen in this patient. The laboratory findings of elevated TSH and decreased free T4 are inconsistent with the suppressed TSH and elevated thyroid hormones expected in Graves disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Acute suppurative thyroiditis presents with acute onset of fever, severe neck pain, and tenderness. The chronic presentation, absence of fever, and painless thyroid enlargement exclude this rare bacterial infection of the thyroid gland.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman who was recently diagnosed with Hashimoto thyroiditis presents with a 3-day history of palpitations, insomnia, and loose stools. She was advised to repeat laboratory studies before starting levothyroxine treatment. Vital signs are BP, 140/85; P, 110. Physical examination shows a slightly enlarged, nontender thyroid. Laboratory results show TSH 0.1 mcU/mL (normal 0.4–4.0) and free T4 2.5 ng/dL (normal 0.9–1.7). What best explains her current presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While patients can theoretically have both conditions, the development of concurrent Graves disease in a patient with established Hashimoto thyroiditis would be extremely rare. The clinical presentation and laboratory findings are more consistent with the transient thyrotoxic phase of existing autoimmune thyroid disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Subacute granulomatous thyroiditis can cause destructive thyrotoxicosis with similar laboratory findings, but typically presents with a painful goiter, fever, and elevated inflammatory markers following a viral illness. This patient's painless presentation in the setting of known Hashimoto thyroiditis is more consistent with a different diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Thyroid storm is a life-threatening condition characterized by severe hyperthyroid symptoms with systemic decompensation including high fever, altered mental status, and cardiovascular collapse. This patient's presentation, while consistent with thyrotoxicosis, lacks the severity and systemic manifestations required for this diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Myxedema coma is a life-threatening complication of severe hypothyroidism characterized by impaired mental status, hypothermia, and cardiovascular collapse, with laboratory findings showing elevated TSH and low T4 levels. This patient presents with hyperthyroid symptoms and suppressed TSH with elevated free T4, which is not consistent with myxedema coma.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – Hashitoxicosis represents transient thyrotoxicosis occurring in patients with Hashimoto thyroiditis due to follicular rupture of hormone-containing thyroid tissue. This phenomenon can occur even in patients on stable levothyroxine therapy and explains the paradoxical hyperthyroid symptoms and laboratory findings in a patient with established Hashimoto thyroiditis. This transient phase will eventually resolve as thyroid destruction continues.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the office with a six-month history of progressive fatigue, a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight gain despite no change in diet, and constipation. She has a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus. Her heart rate is 58/min, and blood pressure is 128/84 mm Hg. On physical examination, her skin is cool and dry. The thyroid gland is diffusely enlarged, firm, and non-tender. Deep tendon reflexes show delayed relaxation. Initial laboratory studies show a TSH level of 15.2 mIU/L and a free T4 of 0.6 ng/dL. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Calcitonin is produced by the parafollicular C-cells of the thyroid. Elevated levels are a tumor marker for medullary thyroid carcinoma. This finding is unrelated to the pathophysiology of autoimmune hypothyroidism, which involves destruction of the thyroid follicular cells, and does not align with the patient's clinical presentation.

B) INCORRECT:

Positive thyrotropin (TSH) receptor antibodies are characteristic of Graves disease. These antibodies typically stimulate the TSH receptor, leading to hyperthyroidism. While blocking TSH receptor antibodies can cause hypothyroidism, this is a much rarer occurrence. This patient's clinical picture is one of overt hypothyroidism, making an antibody associated with hyperthyroidism an unlikely cause.

C) INCORRECT:

A decreased radioactive iodine uptake (RAIU) indicates reduced thyroid gland function, which is consistent with this patient's hypothyroid state. However, this finding is not specific to Hashimoto thyroiditis. Other causes of hypothyroidism, such as the hypothyroid phase of subacute thyroiditis or iodine-induced hypothyroidism, would also present with a low RAIU, so it does not establish a specific etiology.

D) CORRECT:

Anti-thyroid peroxidase (anti-TPO) antibodies are present in over 90% of patients with Hashimoto thyroiditis. These antibodies target thyroid peroxidase, a key enzyme in thyroid hormone synthesis, resulting in lymphocytic infiltration, follicular cell destruction, and ultimately, glandular failure. Anti-TPO antibodies are also positive in 70–80% of Graves disease patients. The presence of anti-TPO antibodies is highly sensitive for establishing the autoimmune etiology of this patient's hypothyroidism.
questions.hint: This patient's clinical and laboratory findings confirm primary hypothyroidism. The presence of a firm, non-tender goiter and a history of type 1 diabetes strongly suggests Hashimoto thyroiditis.
